description: Some nontrivial permutation of digits is an odd number.
comments: Also: Odd numbers with more than 2 digits (so you can swap any two digits other than the last one), or numbers having at least one odd digit not in the last position (so you can swap that one with the last digit). - _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 30 2012
formula: a(n) ~ n. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 19 2012
example: The transposition (1,2) (nontrivial permutation of order two) acting on 11 yields the odd number 11. - _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 30 2012
prog: (PARI) is_A007959(n)=bittest(n,0)&n>99 || while(n\=10, bittest(n,0) & return(1)) \\ -  _M. F. Hasler_, Sep 30 2012
author: R. Muller
